dt: {bc}the action of repelling {bc}the force with which bodies, particles, or like forces repel one another

et: Middle English {it}repulsioun,{/it} borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French {it}repulcion, repulsion,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}repulsiōn, repulsiō{/it} {ldquo}action of driving away or expelling{rdquo} (Late Latin, {ldquo}refutation{rdquo}), derivative, with the suffix of verbal action {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} of Latin {it}repellere{/it} "to push away, drive back, fend off " (with {it}-s-{/it} from past participle and verbal noun {it}repulsus{/it}) {ma}{mat|repel|}{/ma}
shortdef: the action of repulsing : the state of being repulsed
the action of repelling : the force with which bodies, particles, or like forces repel one another
